is whether a pending application in revision made under s. 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure , to be referred to hereinafter as the Code , finally abates on the death

concepts.interpretation: Vests discretionary revisional jurisdiction in High Court to examine correctness, legality or propriety of findings, sentences or orders even after death of petitioner, unlike appeals; power to exercise appellate powers or enhance sentence with hearing.

concepts.interpretation: Applies only to appeals: appeals against acquittal abate on death of accused; other appeals except from sentence of fine abate on death of appellant. Does not apply to revisions.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate -Court has set out the case against the accused in these words The charge against the accused was that on the 2nd December, 1946, at Garden Reach, the accused, being an employee as Establishment Clerk of B. C. II Section in the Traffic Accounts Office of B. N. Railway  number Eastern Railway , cheated the said B. N. Railway Administration by dishonestly inducing it by means of false representation in the pay bill of the number-gazetted staff for November, 1946, to deliver to him Rs. 205-13-0 and to one Satish Chandra Das Gupta, a clerk in the said B. C. 11 Section, Rs. 33-4-0 in excess of legitimate dues, and thereby companymitted an offence punishable under section 420, P.C.

Every appeal under section 411A, subsection  2 , or section 417 shall finally abate on the death of the accused, and every other appeal under this Chapter  except an appeal from a sentence of fine  shall finally abate on the death of the appellant.

issues.text: whether a pending application in revision made under s. 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, to be referred to hereinafter as the Code, finally abates on the death of the petitioner in the High Court, and if so, to what extent.

anchor.surface_text: is whether a pending application in revision made under s. 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure  to be referred to hereinafter as the Code , finally abates on the death of the petitioner in the High Court, and if so, to what extent.

issues.text: whether there is any provision in the Code, which limits the discretionary power of the High Court to examine the correctness, legality or propriety of any finding, sentence or order - s. 435, passed by any inferior Court.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 439 of the Code, the discretion is vested in the High Court to exercise such of the powers of an Appellate Court, as may be attracted to the case, and it has also the power to enhance a sentence subject to the proviso that noorder to the prejudice of an accused person, shall be made unless he has had the opportunity of being heard. In the instant case, we are not concerned with the question of enhancement of sentence we are concerned with the question whether there is any provision in the Code, which limits the discretionary power of the High Court to examine the correctness, legality or propriety of any finding, sentence or order -  s. 435 , passed by any inferior Court.

issues.text: whether the High Court was right in limiting its power of revision to the question of fine only - whether it was proper or excessive - without going into the merits of the order of conviction.
whether the principle of s. 431 applies to criminal revisional applications.

anchor.surface_text: There is no relevant provision in the Code, except s. 431 which is the last section in Chapter XXXI of the Code, dealing with appeals, and is in these terms- Every appeal under section 411A, subsection  2 , or section 417 shall finally abate on the death of the accused, and every other appeal under this Chapter  except an appeal from a sentence of fine  shall finally abate on the death of the appellant. It is manifest that the section, in terms, applies only to appeals

arguments.claim: Principle of s.431 CrPC applies to criminal revisional applications even with composite sentence, but only insofar as sentence of fine is concerned; conviction cannot be challenged

anchor.surface_text: holding that the principle of s. 431 of the Code, applied to a criminal revisional application even when there was a composite sentence but only in so far as the sentence of fine was concerned. The application for substitution was,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Act X of 1872 , did number companyfer any right of appeal on the legal representative after the death of the companyvict, the appeal companyld numbe

arguments.court_reasoning: s.431 in terms applies only to appeals; no provision for revisions; revision is discretionary power not statutory right

arguments.claim: Heir of deceased accused should be substituted as party to challenge order of conviction and sentence in revision

anchor.surface_text: The appellant made an application on December 6, 1955, stating that he was one of the heirs of the deceased accused (petitioner in the High Court), and that he was interested in proceeding with the criminal revision case, and challenging the order of conviction and sentence, passed against his deceased father.

arguments.court_reasoning: Revisional jurisdiction does not abate on death; High Court has discretion to allow substitution and examine conviction and fine

arguments.claim: s.431 CrPC applies only to appeals, not to revisions

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the section, in terms, applies only to appeals, and lays down that an appeal against an order of acquittal passed by the High Court in exercise of its original criminal jurisdiction (s. 411-A (2)), or an appeal to the High Court from an order of acquittal passed by any court other than the High Court,

arguments.claim: Revisional powers under s.439 CrPC read with s.435 do not create any right in litigant but conserve High Court's power to ensure justice; unlike statutory right of appeal

anchor.surface_text: The revisional powers of the High Court vested in it by s. 439 of the Code, read with s. 435, do not create any right in the litigant, but only conserve the power of the High Court to see that justice is done in accordance with the recognized rules of Criminal Jurisprudence, and that subordinate criminal courts do not exceed their jurisdiction,

arguments.claim: Legislature did not intend s.431 abatement to apply to revisions as no provision enacted despite awareness of precedents; revisions governed by discretion

anchor.surface_text: We may assume that the Legislature was aware of the decision of the Bombay High Court, referred to above, when it enacted s. 431 for the first time in the Code of 1882. If the Legislature intended that all application in revision pending in a High Court, should be dealt with on the same footing as a pending appeal, it would have enacted accordingly.

arguments.claim: High Court has complete discretion on pending revision on death of petitioner; not bound to abate even with composite sentence
Bombay High Court majority decision in Imperatrix v. Dongaji Andaji lays down correct approach: revision power survives death unlike appeal
Single judge decisions applying s.431 principle to revisions by analogy are incorrect
High Court cannot limit revision to fine only; must examine conviction merits as fine depends on it
No provision limits High Court's discretionary power under s.439 to examine correctness, legality or propriety of findings even post death

holdings.text: A pending application in revision under s.439 CrPC does not finally abate on the death of the petitioner; the High Court has complete discretion to continue the proceedings, allow substitution of heirs, and decide the matter including the merits of conviction and sentence of fine.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.431 expressly limited to appeals; no equivalent for revisions; revision is discretionary supervisory power not statutory right; legislature did not extend abatement; precedents like Bombay HC support continuation in aid of justice.

holdings.text: Section 431 CrPC applies only to appeals and not to criminal revisional applications.

anchor.surface_text: There is no relevant provision in the Code, except s. 431 which is the last section in Chapter XXXI of the Code, dealing with appeals, and is in these terms- Every appeal under section 411A, subsection  2 , or section 417 shall finally abate

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain textual reading: 'the section, in terms, applies only to appeals'; Chapter XXXI deals with appeals; no mention of revisions in Chapter XXXII.

holdings.text: Revisional jurisdiction under ss.435 and 439 CrPC is a discretionary power to supervise justice, not a statutory right vesting in the litigant like an appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The revisional powers of the High Court vested in it by s. 439 of the Code, read with s. 435, do not create any right in the litigant, but only conserve the power of the High Court to see that justice is done in accordance with the recognized rules of Criminal Jurisprudence,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes statutory appeal right (subject to abatement) from discretionary revision to prevent jurisdictional error or injustice; no right to substitution but court power persists.

holdings.text: The High Court erred in limiting revisional jurisdiction to the sentence of fine alone and must examine the merits of the conviction where proceedings continue post-death.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Fine legality depends on conviction validity; full revisional power under s.439 includes examining findings/sentence; cannot artificially limit once jurisdiction invoked.

holdings.text: No provision in CrPC limits the High Court's discretionary revisional power to examine correctness, legality or propriety of inferior court findings, sentences or orders even after petitioner's death.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 439 of the Code, the discretion is vested in the High Court to exercise such of the powers of an Appellate Court, as may be attracted to the case, and it has also the power to enhance a sentence subject to the proviso that no order to the prejudice of an accused person,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.439 vests broad powers without abatement limit; contrasts with appeals; exercised per case exigencies for justice.

holdings.text: The majority decision in Imperatrix v. Dongaji Andaji (Bombay HC) lays down the correct approach for criminal revisions absent statutory abatement provisions.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Approves view that revision survives death unlike appeal; rejects minority; aligns with no statutory bar.

anchor.surface_text: before a Division Bench of the Bombay High Court in its criminal revisional jurisdiction in the case of In re Nabishab  1 . Shortly stated, the facts in that case were that two persons had been convicted of criminal breach of trust, and each one was sentenced to one years rigorous. imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 1,000.

precedents.cited_proposition: Relative of deceased appellant applied in revisional jurisdiction to set aside conviction and sentence and refund fine after appeal abated; High Court refused as it depended on appreciation of evidence

precedents.citation: Imperatrix v. Dongaji Andaji 1 1878 I.L.R. 2 Bom. 564

anchor.surface_text: Such a situation arose in the case of Imperatrix v. Dongaji Andaji  1 . In that case, the accused person was sentenced, on a charge of forgery, to four years rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 1,000 by the Court of Session.

precedents.cited_proposition: Appeal abates on death of appellant even if sentence includes fine; High Court retains revisional jurisdiction but majority held no continuation by legal representative and limited revision
precedents.cited_holding: Appeal abates on death; no right for legal representative to continue appeal; revisional powers may be exercised

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, the Bombay majority decision  1 , in the absence of any statutory provisions in respect of criminal revisional cases, lays down the correct approach.

precedents.cited_proposition: Majority decision lays down correct approach to abatement and revision on death of convicted person

outcome.relief_summary: Criminal revision does not abate on death of petitioner; High Court can examine conviction and sentence of fine on merits at instance of legal representative
directions: High Court to exercise revisional power without limitation to sentence of fine only, including examination of conviction
